Ralph.goal: Find a 30-minute meeting on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 that fits all participants' schedules.

Peter.goal: Find a 30-minute meeting on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 that fits all participants' schedules.

private_information: Preference: avoid meetings on Monday after 13:30 if possible
Daniel.goal: Find a 30-minute meeting on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 that fits all participants' schedules while respecting preferences.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate participants' availabilities and produce a PDDL domain and problem (for the FastDownwards solver) that encodes a valid 30-minute meeting time satisfying all constraints and preferences.

public_information: Schedule a 30-minute meeting on Monday within work hours 09:00-17:00.
All participants (Ralph, Peter, Daniel) must be available for the chosen slot.
There exists at least one solution that fits everyone's existing schedule.
Daniel prefers to avoid meetings after 13:30 on Monday if possible.

availability.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar participant. Interpret your private schedule and return your available 30-minute slots on the specified day within the work hours. Provide the availability as a concise structured list (e.g., ["09:00-09:30", "10:00-10:30"]). Do not produce PDDL.
availability.prompt: Your name is Ralph. Here is the public information: {environment->public_information} Your private schedule: {agents->Ralph->private_information} Your goal: {agents->Ralph->goal} Considering the meeting duration and work hours, list the 30-minute time slots on Monday when you are available. If you need to indicate preferences, include them clearly alongside availability.

availability.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar participant. Interpret your private schedule and return your available 30-minute slots on the specified day within the work hours. Provide the availability as a concise structured list (e.g., ["09:00-09:30", "10:00-10:30"]). Do not produce PDDL.
availability.prompt: Your name is Peter. Here is the public information: {environment->public_information} Your private schedule: {agents->Peter->private_information} Your goal: {agents->Peter->goal} Considering the meeting duration and work hours, list the 30-minute time slots on Monday when you are available. If you have no additional preferences, state so.

availability.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar participant. Interpret your private schedule and return your available 30-minute slots on the specified day within the work hours. Also clearly state any soft preferences (times to avoid). Provide the availability as a concise structured list. Do not produce PDDL.
availability.prompt: Your name is Daniel. Here is the public information: {environment->public_information} Your private schedule and preferences: {agents->Daniel->private_information} Your goal: {agents->Daniel->goal} Considering the meeting duration and work hours, list the 30-minute time slots on Monday when you are available, and indicate that you prefer to avoid meetings after 13:30 if possible.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert orchestrator for multi-agent scheduling. Your job is to take the participants' declared availability lists and preferences and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem encoding the scheduling task, targeting the FastDownwards planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep each participant's potential actions distinct and ensure the problem models a single 30-minute meeting slot on Monday within 09:00-17:00 that is free for all participants. Respect soft preferences where possible (prefer earlier slots before 13:30 for Daniel).
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Inputs provided: {workflow->orchestrator->pddl->input} and the public environment information: {environment->public_information}. Each input contains a participant's available 30-minute slots and any preferences. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem (for FastDownwards) that encodes selecting one valid 30-minute slot satisfying all hard constraints and respecting Daniel's preference when possible. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem>.
